newsitem.title: FRANCE: FORECAST - French 1997 growth seen at 2.5 pct - BIPE.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - French 1997 growth seen at 2.5 pct - BIPE.

text.p: French consultancy BIPE said on Thursday it expected the economy to grow by 2.5 percent in 1997, above the government's 2.3 percent forecast, but that France would miss the strict three percent Maastricht Treaty deficit criteria.
"Despite the brake on public spending and growth a little stronger than that expected in the Finance Bill, the slowdown in the needs of the public finances is not assured," BIPE said in a statement.
BIPE said it expected the budget deficit, according to Maastricht calculations, to be 3.2 percent of gross domestic product in 1997, falling to 2.9 percent in 1998.
The private consultancy was upbeat on growth, saying its 1997 forecast could well be surpassed and that the French economy should expand by three percent next year.

It said 1997 growth would be driven mainly by stock rebuilding and a rise in exports and to a lesser degree capital spending. It said the pickup in growth in 1998 would be more the result of reinvestment in capital goods than final consumption.

BIPE said, however, the unemployment rate looked set to remain high in France and it would be difficult for growth alone to reduce mass unemployment. It predicted a jobless rate of 12.4 percent in 1997 and 11.9 percent in 1998.
The group's forecasts are used, along with seven other groups' forecasts, by France's accounts auditing commission.
BIPE Conseil is funded by consultants Stratorg and French state-owned bank Caisse des Depots et Consignations.
